texts.shortText: Medium-sized, mid-water schooling fish with large eyes; dorsal fin with spinose anterior section taller than posterior rayed section and separated from it by deep dip. Colour pale-green above, silvery below, a small black patch on gill covers. Lateral line armed with bony scute-like scales and distinctly kinked downwards half way along body.
Reach 70 cm, but in-shore schools usually of much smaller individuals.

Global: Widespread across eastern Atlantic from Norway to South Africa, including Mediterranean, and around the South African coast to Eastern Cape, where it is replaced by the African maasbanker T. delagoa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Eastern Cape.

Medium-sized, midwater species that occurs in large schools. An important fishery species and also significant component of the diets of various larger predatory fish. Undergo diurnal migrations, moving closer to the surface at night. An important commercial species, exploited mostly by mid-water trawls. Juveniles sometimes school with other species.
Filer feeder, straining small planktonic species from the water column using the enlarged gill rakers. The bulk of the diet comprises euphausiids.

Sexual maturity is reached at a length of about 20 cm and at an age of 3 years and the sex ratio is 1:1. Spawning occurs form June to November with two spawning peaks. The eggs develop in the plankton.
Could be confused with various other silvery schooling fish, such as pilchard or chub mackerel, but the armoured and kinked lateral line is a distinctive character.
